stem: A 30-year-old client with a history of hyperthyroidism is in the PACU following a subtotal thyroidectomy. She suddenly develops extreme muscle rigidity and a core temperature of 105.1째F. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: This is Jane Doe, a 30-year-old female who underwent a subtotal thyroidectomy at 09:00 today. She is now in the PACU and exhibiting signs of a hyperthermic crisis. Her core temperature is 105.1째F.
Background: The client has a history of hyperthyroidism. Intraoperatively, she received succinylcholine and isoflurane.
Assessment: At 11:15, the client's jaw was noted to be locked (masseter spasm), and her skin is mottled. Heart rate is 158 bpm, and end-tidal CO2 is elevated at 82 mmHg. Muscle tone is rigid.
Recommendation: I recommend immediate stabilization and evaluation for possible malignant hyperthermia versus thyroid storm. We need to administer dantrolene and initiate cooling measures STAT.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP: 168/94 mmHg, HR: 158 bpm, RR: 32 breaths/min, T: 105.1째F (40.6째C), ETCO2: 82 mmHg

actionOptions.text: Administer IV dantrolene sodium immediately as prescribed.
Initiate cooling protocols (cold saline, ice to axilla/groin).
Administer STAT IV propranolol to treat the hyperthyroid component.
Encourage the client to take deep breaths to lower the CO2.

parameterOptions.text: End-tidal CO2 (ETCO2) and core temperature trends
Muscle rigidity status and serum CK/potassium levels
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This is malignant hyperthermia (MH) (c2). While thyroid storm (c1) is a valid concern given the patient's history, the extreme end-tidal CO2 (82 mmHg), elevated CK (12,000 U/L), and 'lead-pipe' muscle rigidity (specifically lockjaw/masseter spasm) are hallmarks of MH, triggered by succinylcholine or volatile anesthetic gases. Priority #1 is the specific antidote, dantrolene (a1), which inhibits calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. Priority #2 is rapid cooling (a2) to reduce metabolic demand and prevent further hyperthermia. Key parameters include tracking the ETCO2 (the earliest sign of MH) (p1) and monitoring for rhabdomyolysis/potassium spikes related to the muscle rigidity (p2).
clinicalPearls: The earliest sign of MH is a sudden, often dramatic, rise in end-tidal CO2 (ETCO2), NOT the fever. The capnography waveform will also show an increase.
Dantrolene is the only muscle relaxant that directly treats the underlying calcium-release problem in MH. It does NOT reverse the effects of neuromuscular blockers.
A family history of anesthesia complications (especially unexplained fevers or muscle rigidity) is the most important risk screening tool for MH.

questionTrap.trap: Treating this as a thyroid storm because the patient has a history of Graves' disease.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on the muscle tone and lab values. Thyroid storm causes tremors and agitation, not rigidity. MH causes 'stone-like' rigidity and a locked jaw (masseter spasm). Also, check the ETCO2 and CK; they will be much higher in MH.

mnemonic.title: M-H-D
mnemonic.expansion: M-Muscle rigidity. H-High CO2/Temp. D-Dantrolene is the drug.
